segments.text: For two days, Yuhuda wanted to see what was happening at the pink house.

To check whether she left everything as it was, knowing that despite his spontaneous gesture to let her stay there, it might not be easy for her to face the house again, which had been hers for as long as she could remember.
Upon returning home after leaving her there, he sat for a long time with his wife Vicky and told her the whole series of events.
He told her about meeting the singer, the unexpected arrival of the girl and their conversation until she asked to stay there.
Vicki also understood at once that the girl probably had nowhere else to be and that it was an excellent solution, temporary as it might be.
His wife has a good soul.
When the possibility of buying the house at a bargain came up, she wasn't sure they needed it.
But he convinced her it was a great investment and that it could always be sold as four separate houses for double the profit.
She trusted him.
He is a hard-working guy with a good head on his shoulders, and if he says so, he likely knows.
But from the moment he bought it, he didn't rush to do anything with it.
Something held him back from selling the place, and he was busy with his work in the South at that time anyway.
Vicki tried to calculate what was left for Joseph from that entire sale.
After all, the money went to cover debts to Aphrodur and the banks, and due to the foreclosure forced upon them, only after the entire legal process would they receive the remainder.
How sad, she said to Yehuda, such a lively house as if it died with Lucy.
And what is the little girl's fault?
You'd be surprised.
She's not so little anymore.
You know, he said thoughtfully.
She sat and talked to me so maturely, almost rebuking me for doing nothing with the house and saying it looked neglected and withered.
I was so embarrassed.
I didn't know what to say to her.
Remember how the mailman told us she watered Lucy's garden so that if Lucy watched from above, she wouldn't be sad that the garden was neglected?
Just because of that story, I sometimes turn on the sprinklers to ease my conscience.
But that garden, which was glorious, is vanishing.
For two days, he refrained from going to check on the house, and now, before heading south, he made his way to the pink house, knowing that Leora was back in the army.
He took the key from behind the shutters on the kitchen window sill and carefully opened the door.
A smell of cleanliness hit his nose.
He opened the shutters and light flooded the dining room.
Immediately, he noticed the pictures hung back on the walls.
The tables and chairs were perfectly arranged, and on one table stood a beer glass with yellow chrysanthemums.
He went to the kitchen and found washed dishes on a towel.
Everything was clean and shining, as if an invisible hand had turned back time in the house.
He let out a sigh, whose meaning he couldn't decipher, something between relief and unease.
Yehuda made his way back to the dining room and opened the glass doors leading to the garden.
They gleamed, and the garden was visible in its clarity.
Although neglected, it was evident it had been watered.
He sat heavily in their armchair, and only when he lifted his head for a moment did he notice the jar with the letter on the reception desk.
He jumped, grabbed the letter, and began reading it, leaning on the desk.
When he finished, he felt a lump in his throat.
What's happening to him for heaven's sake?
The girl is striking hidden cords within him.
He didn't touch the money in the jar.
He wouldn't take her money.
No doubt, she had worked here for hours, cleaning the house and rooms for months of accumulated dust and filth.
washed hung laundry and changed sheets.
Why would he take her money?
He thought maybe she should do something with the place on weekends until he decided its fate.
Meanwhile, she would have a few bucks as she put it.
He looked around and knew she was right.
Yosef's pictures instantly transformed the house back to being the pink house and now with them hanging on the walls, the place needed to be locked.
Just before leaving, his eyes fell on the empty space where the piano once stood.
He paused for a moment and a thought crossed his mind.
A piano was all that was missing for everything to return to its place.
